senlin/profiles/os/nova/server.py.message: What if the service is in state rebooting or similar?
In that case we skip the stopping of the VM but still try to rebuild it.  The rebuild might fail.  In that case it's up to the user to retry.

Ok, I did some research and found this page: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/vm-states.html#requirements-for-commands
For the rebuild command, the VM has to be in active or shutoff state or it will not work and return 409.  So I don't need to save the state.  This function will shutdown if the VM is active.  So it can safely assume that the VM is in shutdown state or else the rebuild call will fail anyways.
But what I am afraid of here is that we will wait endlessly for server to move to VS_SHUTOFF at line 1189. Maybe save the current state and use that instead on line 1189?
I assume this code path never starts the VM back up again?
You mean the rebuild?  No, it does not start up a VM if it was in shutoff state.
Returns a tuple of booleans maybe?
This looks fine, but an alternative would be to store the previous state before update (e.g. POWER ON?) and restore it to that state.
I thought about that but I'm not sure if there is a use case for that.  I'll bring it with others and see what they think.

This probably needs to be after this if statement, because we are changing old server status from ACTIVE and then expecting it to be ACTIVE at line 1142, which isn't correct if this if statement is valid.
Yup, definitely a logic flaw :). That's what happens when I try to commit a change on a Friday afternoon.

neutron/agent/securitygroups_rpc.py.message:
Hi Oleg and thanks for the feedback.  

My understanding is that we can have multiple threads in _apply_port_filter() at the same time.  A previous iteration of this fix used a single instance-scoped global lock, but I believe that would lead to another thread releasing the lock early and thus just move the race condition to a new location.

My approach to solve this was to maintain a local lock for each thread that enters _apply_port_filter() (line 144) and then track the most recent thread's lock in the instance-scoped variable (line 64).

We end up with what is effectively a queue of locks where _security_group_updated() associates itself with the most recently enqueued lock and blocks until it is released.  Locks are then dequeued when:

a) a new lock is created and the current lock had nothing waiting on it, or

b) all threads waiting for the lock return from _security_group_updated() 

This allows threads in _security_group_updated() to block for the shortest possible amount time.  They only need to block until the most recent call to _apply_port_filter() returns instead of waiting until all threads have returned.

Please let me know if you see something that I have misunderstood or if this needs further clarification.

I don't think we will need to wait.  My intent was to have  _security_group_updated() wait on the most recent lock (stored in _devices_consistent) at the time it was called.

If another thread starts a new _apply_port_filter() before the previous _apply_port_filter() has completed, the  _devices_consistent variable will be updated but should not affect any threads that were already waiting in _security_group_updated().  Those waiting threads will still have their local reference to the threading.Events() instance that was most recent at the time the thread started waiting.

Hopefully the output below demonstrates what I'm trying to describe.  latest_lock represents the instance-scoped _devices_consistent variable on L64 and wait_on_this_lock represents the instance we're waiting on in L210.

Note that wait_on_this_lock still points to the original address (0x7fc2d89cb130) even after latest_lock is replaced with a new Event() instance (0x7fc2d8689850):

--- 8< ---
# python

>>> import threading
>>> latest_lock = threading.Event()
>>> hex(id(latest_lock))
'0x7fc2d89cb130'
>>> wait_on_this_lock = latest_lock
>>> hex(id(wait_on_this_lock))
'0x7fc2d89cb130'
>>> latest_lock = threading.Event()
>>> hex(id(latest_lock))
'0x7fc2d8689850'
>>> hex(id(wait_on_this_lock))
'0x7fc2d89cb130'
>>> quit()
--- 8< ---

I'm thinking about synchronizing _apply_port_filter() and _security_group_updated() methods with read and write locks from lockutils.ReaderWriterLock(). For example it's used in https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py. Did you consider that?

My earliest attempts at a fix were with lockutils, but at that time I was unable make it fit the problem.  I noticed DHCP agent and some other components using threading.Event(), which seemed like a better fit so I took that route instead.

If there is a strong preference for lockutils please let me know and I can take another look now that I have a better understanding of how the bug can be fixed.

> Is _apply_port_filter() for the port always called first in failure scenario?

In all of the failure scenarios I've traced call-by-call (measured in tens), _apply_port_filter() has always been called first. 

More specifically, the failure only occurs when _security_group_updated() calls self.firewall.ports.values() in L211 AFTER _apply_port_filter() calls security_group_info_for_devices() in L153 to retrieve the remote secgroup membership list but BEFORE it returns from prepare_port_filter on line L175.  When this happens, _security_group_updated() doesn't find a relevant port to apply the secgroup membership update to in L211 - 213, so it returns without doing any further work. 

To try and put it more succinctly, port_update steps #11 - #22 in the diagram [1] are the critical section.  If security_groups_member_updated step #3 occurs during that critical section, the membership update is lost.

> Isn't it possible that for some port _security_group_updated() is called first but the race still happens because of threads switching (after we did wait())?

I don't believe so.  _security_group_updated() is called with a list of secgroup ids.  It then consults self.firewall.ports.values() to see if the hypervisor has any ports that reference the secgroup ids.  If we assume a given secgroup membership update is, or will soon be, relevant to a port on the hypervisor, there are two possible outcomes:

a) The relevant port is NOT yet present in self.firewall.ports.values(). This is normal and happens when we have not yet received a port_update event.  When it does arrive, we will get the secgroup details when _apply_port_filter() calls security_group_info_for_devices() and then configure ipsets appropriately.

b) The relevant port IS already present in self.firewall.ports.values().  This is normal and happens when the port_update event was previously processed.  The port is added to self.devices_to_refilter and will be processed in step #8 [1] on the next CommonAgentLoop.daemon_loop() iteration.

This debug output includes both scenarios and may provide some additional clarity:

--- 8< ---

# Agent restart
Jul 30 14:08:54 bug/1887405: in SecurityGroupAgentRpc.init(). Created initial instance-scoped lock 0x7f1b08849780 in an unlocked state
Jul 30 14:08:54 bug/1887405: in _apply_port_filter for {'tape1d201bf-ad', 'tap9ae9ab15-cf', 'tap9d51114e-20', 'tap014339c3-27'}. Created lock 0x7f1b087c7c18. Replaced 0x7f1b08849780 as most recent.
Jul 30 14:09:04 bug/1887405: in _apply_port_filter for {'tape1d201bf-ad', 'tap9ae9ab15-cf', 'tap9d51114e-20', 'tap014339c3-27'}. Releasing lock 0x7f1b087c7c18.

# _security_group_updated() called before _apply_port_filter()
Jul 30 14:09:08 bug/1887405: in _security_group_updated for {'111face9-83ed-4786-8df8-b4510b08e4a1'}. 0x7f1b087c7c18 is unlocked. Proceed without wait
Jul 30 14:09:08 bug/1887405: in _security_group_updated for {'097c5fda-f53f-46ca-ae7c-14b3c9447954'}. 0x7f1b087c7c18 is unlocked. Proceed without wait
Jul 30 14:09:15 bug/1887405: in _apply_port_filter for {'tap3833ec51-75', 'tap9c3f7763-40'}. Created lock 0x7f1b087c7940. Replaced 0x7f1b087c7c18 as most recent.
Jul 30 14:09:17 bug/1887405: in _security_group_updated for {'133cc1f9-5d18-4a2e-8a7f-f1cd50bb3ba3'}. 0x7f1b087c7940 is locked. Let's wait.
Jul 30 14:09:26 bug/1887405: in _apply_port_filter for {'tap3833ec51-75', 'tap9c3f7763-40'}. Releasing lock 0x7f1b087c7940.
Jul 30 14:09:26 bug/1887405: in _security_group_updated for {'133cc1f9-5d18-4a2e-8a7f-f1cd50bb3ba3'}. Finished waiting on 0x7f1b087c7940

Charles, thanks for such a thorough analysis! I think this just deserves a brief comment before #144 similar to the one at #208-209.

> We end up with what is effectively a queue of locks where
 > _security_group_updated() associates itself with the most recently
 > enqueued lock and blocks until it is released.

But what if another thread starts new _apply_port_filter() while _security_group_updated() is waiting for the event (from previos _apply_port_filter)? Do we now need to wait for this new devices_consistent event?

yep, I got your idea, thanks. Is _apply_port_filter() for the port always called first in failure scenario? Isn't it possible that for some port _security_group_updated() is called first but the race still happens because of threads switching (after we did wait())?
nit: no need as event flag is False after init
consider placing it in 'finally' block to make sure set() is always called. Alternative is to specify some timeout for wait() at #213

Thanks for your patience and coaching on this patch.

I spent a considerable amount of time trying to get this working with threading.Event without success.  It seems like there was some interference between this class and signal handlers in the OVS agent code, which resulted in the process not terminating properly.  Surprisingly, try..finally did not work to force the event state to change so the waiting threads hung indefinitely (or at least beyond the timeout configured in the test case).

Configuring a timeout on the waiter's side did work, but it had to be very short (<5s) as the existing test case was already consuming the majority of the 60 second default.  This approach seemed sort of hacky and, without a bunch of sampling from production environments, I was not able to come up with a timeout value that wasn't completely arbitrary.

The threading.Condition class does not seem to cause the same problem with signal handlers.  oslo_concurrency's ReaderWriterLock uses it under the hood, so I re-implemented using that and FirewallMigrationTestCase now passes.  I'll push the new patch set shortly.

oslo_policy/policy.py.message:
Concerned that the logic here is going to mess people up.  I think that the oslo.conf logic does not distinguish between the default value and an explicit value.  If there is an explicit value for the new file, but the old (json) file is still in place, I think it will silently grab the old file.  

I think there needs to be logging when it is overriding the default behavior prominent in the log.

It might be better to just break at this point then to fail in the wrong way.

No, old json file would not be picked. That is taken care by if condition at L373 and L376. Also verified by test - https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.policy/+/763261/3/oslo_policy/tests/test_policy.py#1969

If conf.oslo_policy.policy_file is overridden with
-  any value other than 'policy.yaml' then this logic does not do anything and it return the overridden value from L383.
- 'policy.yaml' itself then L376 check the file existence and return the overridden yaml file.

In both cases, json file is not picked. json file will only be picked if 1. service change the default of  conf.oslo_policy.policy_file from 'policy.json' to 'policy.yaml' and deployment still rely on old policy.json then we do not break those deployment and pick old json file for them.

web/.eslintrc.message: Any specific reason why we enforce 1-space indentation for switch statements? I would just use 2-space indentation for those as well. First, I find it a little weird to have a 1-space indentation at all and second, I don't think we should treat switch statements different to the rest?

Felix, please read the docs at https://eslint.org/docs/rules/indent

1 does not mean number of spaces, it means enforce indentation of switch cases, it will use the value defined for normal indents (2).

I would prefer adding a comment here to clarify what the {"SwitchCase": 1} is doing. I took me some time, but according to the eslint documentation it's a factor that's applied to the indentation of switch-case statements based on the default indentation (2 in our case). Thus, the 1 here means 1x2=2 spaces indentation.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/agent/manage.message: I suppose this will also delay initial sriov config update (and thus not allow update_sriov_config() - which performs a forced runtime manifest apply) but not subsequent sriov config update() (since the ports, pci_devices would already be in inventory).  Please confirm this scenario?

Hey John, So I think in the case of a system coming up initially, the sysinv agent will perform it's reporting if it does the inventory before the initial_worker_config_complete flag is set by the controller manifest's 'post' action (so initial_worker_config_completed and worker_config_completed is false).

The worst case scenario would be the sysinv agent for whatever reason attempting to perform it's inventory reporting for the first time _after_ the controller manifest has run, but before the worker manifest has completed (so initial_worker_config_completed is true while worker_config_completed is false).  I'm not even sure this is scenario is possible considering the length the controller manifest takes to run, but in this case the user would not even have the ability to modify an interface or device that is not in the DB, and would have to wait until the worker manifest is complete.

I did have to do some thinking about the scenario of a user locking and unlocking the system in the time window between the end of the worker manifest and the next sysinv agent update (max 60s in the worst case currently).  However, this would not be an issue because the SR-IOV settings from a DB perspective would have been set by the runtime manifest when the system was previously locked, and only updated once the system has fully come up with the worker manifest applied, FPGA reset, and SR-IOV settings re-applied.

Same here, this slightly changes the default. Same for several other config options.
Modified the defaults as per upstream default values for config options.
s/This option have/This option has/
Done
Please include an example for this scenario (ldap-user-enabled-mask=X and ldap-user-enabled-default=Y).
s/ldap_user/ldap-user/
Done

Please use quotes ("512") as you wrote above that the integer should be specified as a string in quotes.

ldap-user-enabled-attribute = "userAccountControl"
ldap-user-enabled-mask = 2
ldap-user-enabled-default = "512"

Also I don't understand the example: 512 with a mask of 2 gives 0, which means the user will be disabled by default? So this contradicts the next sentence?

oh I see, so this is not used as a simple mask, but instead we first add the mask and then apply the mask. So 0 becomes 1, which then matches with 1. I'm wondering if this has been designed with the goal to confuse ;)

Anyway it's not your fault, thanks for digging into this. Can we add a short note/warning here saying that the mask is used in a weird way linking to https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/configuration.html#integrate-identity-back-end-with-ldap ? Thanks!

From https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/configuration.html#integrate-identity-with-ldap:

f the directory server has an enabled attribute, but it is not a boolean type, a mask can be used to convert it. This is useful when the enabled attribute is an integer value. The following configuration highlights the usage:

<same example>

In this case, the attribute is an integer and the enabled attribute is listed in bit 1. If the mask configured user_enabled_mask is different from 0, it retrieves the attribute from user_enabled_attribute and performs an add operation with the user_enabled_mask. If the sum of the operation matches the mask, then the account is disabled.

The value of user_enabled_attribute is also saved before applying the add operation in enabled_nomask. This is done in case the user needs to be enabled or disabled. Lastly, setting user_enabled_default is needed in order to create a default value on the integer attribute (512 = NORMAL ACCOUNT in Active Directory).

Since the various options are explicitly configured now rather than in this options dict, we should deprecate this option.

We should also add a release note that advertises/documents this change.

in order to deprecate this option I think we would need to reverse the precedence (maybe not now, but at some point). However, when the precedence is reversed, it could break existing environments.

Hemanth/Billy, what do you think?

I agree that we shouldn't deprecate ldap-config-flags, at the very least I'm aware of the use of page_size.

About the notice in the release notes, we should announce the new config options and encourage users to migrate their configuration to them since they will be better served in the future in case something requires accommodation in the openstack configuration.

Billy, thoughts?

Also, there are a few other options that are not covered, and could be configured through ldap-config-flags:

page_size
alias_dereferencing
debug_level
chase_referrals
user_mail_attribute
user_pass_attribute
user_description_attribute
... 
and so on. See https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/b0b93c03986f3bb40c5a2ec31ee37c83014e197a/keystone/conf/ldap.py#L153

I believe this is a strong argument against the deprecation of this option. If we then decide to not deprecate it, do you think a release note is still deserved?

Did you want to flip this around to `ldap-tls-ca`? 
For consistency purposes.
this cannot be flipped at this time because there may be users already using it as it is, and it would break them if it is changed

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Remove this. 

Add a bit more of an explanation. Is the reason for the delay because there was invalid addresses in the list of ceph monitors (i.e. controller-0 host IP, controller-1 host IP, and floating IP) and depending on which was selected by the RBD driver it would take 30s to timeout and find the correct address? 

Any chance you tested a swact during a live migration with this change? Wondering if there is fallout from IP switchover?

'ceph mon dump' is a user space command that uses ceph lubraries (librados I believe) to connect to a cluster.
If not specified as arguments, the command reads ceph.conf to get the addresses of all the monitors then opens sockets to them and, since 2 out of 3 addresses don't point to valid monitors, it leads to delayed response.

I don't know the internal implementation of 'ceph' command, if it tries to connect to monitors one by one, in which order or what is considered a connection failure (why timeout is sometimes instantaneous and other times it takes almost a minute). Nevertheless, we know that the implementation is not ok and leading to the error.

More context: I remember an older discussion on one of the mailing lists that cited exactly this problem in another command (I believe it was 'rbd') and that they wanted to change the behaviour to something like:
1. grab the list of monitors
2. try to connect to all monitors at the same time by spawning a thread for each monitor address
3. on first successful connection kill the other threads and continue with this one
Yet I don't know in what version they dit it, if it is done for all cli commands and if it is working flawlessly.
So nothing to do with RBD Ceph libs or driver (at least not in this case).

kuryr_kubernetes/cni/daemon/service.py.message:
Are we sure that all ProcessExecutionError exceptions will come from ovs only? For example, sriov driver exec's "ip link set .." kind of commands that can fail and generate same exception. Assuming it to be ovs-vsctl is maybe not really correct.

I think service.py should have general exception handling, which is common to all drivers.
It might be better to use a custom exception such OVSExecutionError. But I am not sure if it is really needed.

If we simply print a generic message, then this doesn't add too much in addition to what default Exception handler below provides (_check_failure() will eventually mark cni unhealthy).

In case of sriov binding driver, error may be caused due to factors outside of kuryr cni (like race condition or timeout in iproute2 commands, driver errors, etc), in which case immediately marking ourselves unhealthy might not be desirable.

I think we should catch specific exceptions where they are generated (ovs binding driver) and wrap them in more general categories for handling here.

I can make the LOG message to be an generic error assuming that the code from where the exception came also prints the error message. This happens in case of OVS but I am not sure about sriov.

Is that acceptable? Or can we deal with it in another way?
LOG.exception would be better. Then you don't need to include exception in the message, it will get added automatically.

Can you make sure code checks the exception's cmd [1] to make sure it's ovs-vsctl? Apparently it's a string, so simple startswith('ovs-vsctl') should be enough (it's hardcoded at [2]):

 In [1]: from oslo_concurrency import processutils

 In [2]: try:
    ...:     processutils.execute('bash -c "exit 1"', shell=True)
    ...: except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as e:
    ...:     print e.cmd
    ...:     print type(e.cmd)
    ...:     
 bash -c "exit 1"
 <type 'unicode'>


[1] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.concurrency/ocata/api/processutils.html#oslo_concurrency.processutils.ProcessExecutionError
[2] https://github.com/openstack/os-vif/blob/0c6a21c06406ca942c92e39a4a2b3fab61fefb60/vif_plug_ovs/ovsdb/impl_vsctl.py#L100

I still think it is not the best practice to handle this exception here, when we can be more granular and handle it in the driver which actually uses ovs, instead of polluting service.py with driver-specific code.
True, though it's both VIFOpenVSwitchDriver and os-vif that do ovs-vsctl. Both are run in base.connect(). Maybe we can put it there?

Yes but then we lose the access to healthy variable. If we want to take a quick action to resolve this error then we need to have it in service.py. 

I do agree that the base.connect() might be the best place to catch this exception but since we won't have access to healthy variable we can't do much after raising that exception. It doesn't make a lot of sense to have this.

Another option is to have a new class of exceptions (the fatal exceptions) which require us to restart the cni at once.

Seems line the semantics of the method does not match to what, in fact, is returned from the method. The method returns a CodeSource object with just one field "version", not the value of the field. Please fix it to avoid any confusions.
All methods that are not part of the class API (find, find_all) should start with an underscore.
I know it's Python and it allows to treat any not empty objects as boolen True but I would still prefer to add " is not None" at the end.

Exists where? Maybe we need to clearly call it "...exists_in_db"? Otherwise, the method "load_existing_action" looks weird because you kind of do the following: if the action doesn't exist (somewhere, my first guess was in self._action_descs), then delete it from self._action_descs.
Maybe it's also worth adding a comment that this is needed to delete it from the internal cache.
This argument doesn't exist in the signature of the method in the base class. You can't change it.
No need in a blank line right after the signature.
No need in a blank line right after the signature.

I'm failing to understand what is going on here... Why do you do this? I can guess it's because you want to make sure that every object got into the interal cache. And if it's already there then another DB query won't be made. But if we're not lucky, then every object that we've just loaded from DB will be loaded again with an individual query. Anyway, it's very very hard to understand what we have here. Please decompose this logic in a different way. For example, introduce another internal method that both "find" and "find_all" would use.

docs/source/developers.md.message: what is this CIDR range? and its purpose?
This cidr is used for the ephemeral, target1, worker1 nodes. without this, the install script cannot reach the ephemeral node, because it goes to the proxy and hangs there.
calling corporate DNS servers internal is redundant and a bit confusing.
you talk about DNS nameservers above and proxy here. can you please clear on what needs set in the below files you mention?

It is the chicken and egg problem. The upstream configuration uses the public google dns servers, like 8.8.8.8 for name resolution.
If you are behind a proxy, however, (for instance myproxy.mycorp.com:port), you will need to resolve this proxy name in a dns before you connect to the proxy to break out. you cannot use 8.8.8.8 to resolve myproxy.mycorp.com name yet, you have to go your your corporate dns for this.

As written, this field implies that a Secret has some variable number of certificates. However TLS Secrets must have both exactly one certificate and one key. This field should probably be separated to represent that.

  certificateExpirationDate   string
  keyExpirationDate           string

no longer true, now it requires it to be set as GLANCE_STORE as well
I don't see this set anywhere
yeah, i think we need a default for this
I am pretty sure these are deprecated nowadays and one is supposed to configure them in their own group (i.e. use "backends" in glance).
not sure what you mean by deprecated but the values set here will be the project in which cinder will create the image-volume

There are 2 cases, single store and multiple store.
1) for single store, these configs are loaded from [glance_store]
2) for multiple stores, we define a group name against every store used like cinder:fast, file:slow
then we have groups like [fast] and [slow]

I'm not sure if we have devstack configuration in place for setting up multiple stores via devstack.
1) if we have, then all the store configuration (see swift above) uses the default [glance_store] group so everything will require refactoring and not this specifically
2) if we don't have then this works completely fine with the default [glance_store] group

Either way, for a gate run i think single store installation would be preferable as we prefer for cinder single backend by default.

Yeah, I know what they do. But the modern glance config wants you to put them in a dedicated group, see https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/configuration/glance_api.html#glance-store (especially the parts in red ;-) ).
can't we call it backend? or even c_backend
can we make it somewhat better and not require this? this is also question to the glance team - maybe it needs better packaging?
Yeah, I wish someone from glance could advise.
this doesn't seem the best way but in the current scenario how these rootwrap files exist in glance_store, this seemed to be the only way.

stack.sh.message:
as mentioned in my previous comment, we need a check here to wait for cinder-volume to be publishing capabilities else image upload will fail
we can check like
if [ "$GLANCE_STORE" = "cinder" ]; then
    sleep 30
this is pretty worrying and might have weird impact if we need 31 seconds instead ;-) can't we check whether cinder is already up?

i don't think there is any API in cinder which tells if the backend is publishing capabilities on the scheduler or not.
i think we can sleep for 1 minute (which is the time for a backend to publish capabilities) and if still it doesn't then there's some problem with c-vol and we shouldn't proceed with the installation anyway.
Maybe just poll the cinder API here? It can be a simple loop with sleeps and a set number of repeats (to try only for max e.g. 2 minutes).

From the gate run, i saw the difference as 4 seconds.
from multiple local runs, the results varied but for the slowest run on my slow system, it went as high as 20 seconds.
the default backend_stats_polling_interval is 60 seconds which i didn't find valid waiting for as during the actual run, most of the time of 60 sec is already spend while reaching this step.
I didn't find any other way to do it as i found this issue in logs (which also took a lot of time finding as wasn't obvious).
kindly suggest if you've any better way to do the same.

openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/ins.message:
Calling the server list API twice is not a lightweight task.

I wonder the first call of _get_instance() is really required. Looking at the code here, the result of the first _get_instance() is used  to determine the interested instance ID for _get_images(). The purpose of _get_images() is to get a corresponding image ID that is passed to the nova server list API.

However, when 'image_name' is passed as a filter, you can get a corresponding image ID just by calling the image list API of glance with a query parameter like 'images?name=<specified image name>' [1]. At least it can be done in the glance API. I haven't checked it can be done via glanceclient and the horizon API wrapper, but avoiding the same API call twice is much appreciated.

As summary, my suggestion is if non API filter(s) are passed, let's resolve names first before calling the server list API. Otherwise let's retrieve related image information after calling the server list API.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/image/v2/index.html?expanded=list-images-detail#list-images
